Landing.featuresTitle: Facilitating the understanding of the Sun through technology
Landing.featuresDescription:
Designed to be intuitive and accessible, this dashboard simplifies
 the study of solar activity, democratizing access to complex data
 and transforming it into comprehensible knowledge for everyone.
Landing.feature1Description:
With images captured by the SOHO space observatory, this
 dashboard allows you to explore images of the Sun in different
 ultraviolet layers. Observe solar phenomena from multiple
 perspectives and understand its dynamics like never before.
Landing.feature2Description:
Analyze the evolution of critical solar parameters over time with
 detailed metrics such as entropy, fractal dimension, and spectral
 analysis. These tools provide deep insight into solar activity and
 its impact on long-term phenomena.
Landing.feature3Description:
Discover an educational space designed for students and
 teachers. This dashboard offers simulations, educational
 visualizations, and lessons on solar phenomena, making it easier
 to learn about topics like solar cycles, sunspots, and
 geomagnetic storms.
Landing.teamDescription:
We are the team behind Luma, passionate about sharing knowledge
 about the Sun. If you have questions, ideas, or want to share your
 observations, contact us. Together we can expand our
 understanding of the universe.
Landing.footerSubtitle: A new way to study solar activity

ChartsParameters.entropyDescription: Entropy is typically calculated from the image histogram, which represents the frequency distribution of pixel intensity levels. When an image has a uniform intensity distribution, meaning all levels are equally probable, entropy is high due to greater uncertainty or disorder. Conversely, if an image has a highly skewed or concentrated distribution, entropy is low, indicating less uncertainty or disorder. High diversity in an image generally implies low entropy.
ChartsParameters.meanIntensityDescription: Mean intensity in image processing represents the average intensity value of all pixels in an image. Each pixel in a digital image has an associated intensity value corresponding to its brightness or color. Mean intensity is calculated by summing all pixel intensity values and dividing by the total number of pixels. This measure is important for detecting objects or regions of interest, as it provides insights into scene illumination levels.
ChartsParameters.standardDeviationDescription: Standard deviation represents the dispersion or variability of pixel intensity values relative to the mean. It indicates how much intensity values deviate from the mean intensity. A high standard deviation suggests more dispersed intensity values, indicating fine details or textures, while a low standard deviation suggests a more uniform or smooth image.
ChartsParameters.fractalDimensionDescription: Fractal dimension is a measure that describes the irregularity or structural complexity of an object or image. Unlike whole numbers, fractal dimension can be a fractional value reflecting roughness or self-similarity across different scales. It is useful for characterizing texture, shape, and complexity in an image and can be applied to distinguish textures or detect fractures.
ChartsParameters.skewnessDescription: Skewness refers to the lack of symmetry or balance in the distribution of pixel intensity values in an image. It is useful for characterizing object shape and intensity distribution. Skewness helps identify elongated or tilted patterns and quantify symmetry in solar dynamics and activity.
ChartsParameters.kurtosisDescription: Kurtosis is a statistical measure describing the shape of the intensity value distribution in an image. It provides insights into the concentration and variability of intensity values and is used in texture analysis, image segmentation, and anomaly detection.
ChartsParameters.uniformityDescription: Uniformity describes the consistency or homogeneity of pixel intensity values across an image. It indicates how balanced the intensity distribution is. Uniformity is important for assessing image quality and consistency, facilitating object detection and segmentation applications.
ChartsParameters.relativeSmoothnessDescription: Relative smoothness measures the variation in pixel intensity across the image.
ChartsParameters.tarumaContrastDescription: Tamura contrast measures the intensity difference between adjacent pixels in the image.
ChartsParameters.tarumaDirectionalityDescription: Tamura directionality assesses the tendency of texture features to align in specific directions, capturing the regularity of patterns in an image.
ChartsParameters.tarumaLinelikenessDescription: Tamura linearity measures the extent to which a texture exhibits features resembling lines or linear elements, useful for detecting cracks or elongated objects in images.
